moves.5. Nc3 Bg7: Black is careless, he should have played dxc4 first.
moves.6... Nb8 7. e4: In just two moves white has gained massive advantage, after just one single mistake by black.
moves.7... O-O 8. Bg5: Strengthening white's grip on the fields d5/e4
moves.8... c6: I investigated returning the pawn with e5, but it brings nothing
moves.9. dxc6 bxc6:
Keeping the option open to attack the center with c6-c5, but at the const of another tempo.
Its probably better than Nxc6 however, as that leaves white's mighty center formation unchallenged
moves.10. Nge2: In order to answer Bg4 with f3.
moves.11... Nd5 12. Bxd5:
Trading this bisshop had to be considered carefully, as the fields h3/g2 are exposed to black bishop.
However after carefull calculations, I deemed the trade safe.
moves.12... cxd5 13. Bxe7: Two pawns up, white has a big advantage now.
moves.13... Re8 14. b4:
Short intermezzo to remove the Queen form the a5-e1 diagonal. 
Also I am improving my pawn formation.
moves.15... Bg4 16. Qb3: using the standalone d5 pawn ad a diversion
moves.16... Bf3: Veru understandable, and at first sight this seems strong. Yet this is the third mistake, giving white an even bigger material lead.
moves.17. Nxd5: Of course, exploiting the fact that Bf3 is exposed.
moves.19... Rad8 20. Qb3: Nice try, but I am not falling into such traps.
moves.24... Qb7: Another mistake, which makes life easier for white
moves.25. Rc5c7 Qd5: Forced, byut now I can trade Queens...
moves.26. Qxd5 Rxd5 27. Rxa7:
And win another pawn, and occupy the 7th rank.
Jummy
moves.27... f5 28. Rcc7 Bf8 29. Rcxh7: And another pawn, but it could not be saved by any means
moves.29... Rc8 30. Rhc7: Not allowing even the slightest counter play
moves.30... Rdd8 31. b5: If RxR, Rxr, Bxa3 then b6 wins quickly.
moves.31... Rcb8 32. a4 Rb6 33. f4: White decides to manouver a bit, before the pawns start marching. Its probably a bit slow.
moves.33... Rbb8 34. Kf2 Rb6: Black has no plan and real good moves.
moves.37... Rba8: Hoping for RxR, after which the a pawn falls.
moves.38. Nd5: Another nice move, made possible by my large pawn advantage. Blak must trade rooks, or he willbe checkmated.
Again not allwoing black any counterplay
moves.41... Ba3 42. b6: Finally the pawn amrches, and this time she is unstoppable.
moves.44. a5 Ke6 45. Nb6: Blocking the kings route to the pawns
moves.45... Ke7 46. a6: Black surrendered, he has no defence left against Ra8
